thread.title: San Jose State, San Diego State play with much at stake
thread.title_full: San Jose State, San Diego State play with much at stake

author:
Jeff Faraudo

jfaraudo@bayareanewsgroup.com
title: San Jose State, San Diego State play with much at stake
text:
San Jose State, San Diego State play with much at stake By Jeff Faraudo Posted: 10/16/2015 11:04:50 AM PDT Updated: 10/16/2015 11:38:39 AM PDT SpartanCentral blog SAN JOSE -- The San Jose State defense knows what's coming its way on Saturday night. 
It's a San Diego State offensive line that averages 6-foot-5Â½ and 317 pounds and paves the way for Donnel Pumphrey, who already has more than 3,000 career rushing yards midway through his junior season. 
The West Division lead in the Mountain West Conference will be on the line when the Spartans (3-3, 2-1) and Aztecs (3-3, 2-0) collide at Spartan Stadium. 
SJSU is eager to turn the tables after a 38-7 loss in San Diego last year that capped a six-game losing streak and 3-9 final record. 
"This is one of the games we have circled on the calendar," junior linebacker Christian Tago said. "The mindset is just totally different this year. You can just see the hunger in everybody's eyes." San Jose State players, including Keoni Taylor (68), celebrate after defeating UNLV in overtime during an NCAA college football game Saturday, Oct. 10, 2015, in Las Vegas. San Jose State won 33-27. (AP Photo/John Locher) ( John Locher ) 
"We feel like this is a championship game right here," safety Maurice McKnight said. "Everybody's confidence is sky high." 
It will require more than belief to slow down the Aztecs' ground game. It will require muscle. 
Pumphrey rushed for 261 yards and three touchdowns when the teams met last year, powering an offense that piled up 393 rushing yards. In two career games against San Jose, he is averaging 10.9 yards per carry. 
"He's basically San Diego State's Tyler Ervin," Tago said, referring to SJSU's senior tailback who is the nation's No. 2 rusher. 
The Aztecs started 1-3 this season but are gaining momentum. In two conference games, Pumphrey and senior Chase Price have totaled 483 rushing yards. Advertisement 
"We know they're a physical team," SJSU coach Ron Caragher said. "But so are the Spartans in 2015." 
Certainly the Spartans have had plenty of experience defending the run. They played Auburn, Air Force and Oregon State outside the MWC, and those teams ran the ball 163 times for 965 yards against SJSU. 
"Playing someone of the prestige of Auburn gets you ready for any game," Tago said. "I'm just excited to go and see what they can give us." 
Caragher knows a Spartans defense that ranks 10th in the MWC against the run (227.5 yards per game) won't halt the SDSU run game in its tracks. They can only hope to blunt the ground game. 
The key will be first and second down, and forcing a team that doesn't want to throw the ball into uncomfortable third-and-long situations. 
A year ago, the Aztecs averaged 5.6 yards on first down against the Spartans and faced just one third down with more than seven yards to go. 
"That's how they want it to be," Caragher said. 
If the Spartans can make SDSU throw, the odds slant to their favor. SJSU leads the conference in pass defense (117.2 yards per game) and has allowed opponents to complete just 49.3 percent. 
"They don't want to get behind the down and distance because they don't major in throwing the football," Caragher said. 
SDSU senior quarterback Maxwell Smith, a transfer from Kentucky, is connecting on just 46.3 percent and has been sacked 14 times. But he's been sharper in MWC play, completing 16 for 27 for 289 yards and three touchdowns without an interception. Follow Jeff Faraudo on Twitter at twitter.com/Jeff Faraudo.
